required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Warning Labels and College Students' Sugar-Sweetened Beverage Intake
clinical_study.official_title: The Impact of Warning Labels on Reducing College Students' Sugar-Sweetened Beverage Intake

brief_summary.textblock: Sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) are one of the few dietary items causally linked to the development of obesity and chronic disease. SSB consumption among young adults are particularly concerning, because of the high levels of consumption and the influence of disease risk in later life. College students, particularly freshmen, are a captive audience when it comes to dietary consumption because many of them consume their meals in residential dining halls. We are currently working with Michigan Dining to implement warning labels on SSB fountain dispensers to examine whether carefully tailored signage could alter beverage choices of college students. The current study aims to assess changes in dietary intake before and after the labels are posted, in a representative sample of University of Michigan students who eat at residential dining halls.

primary_outcome.description: The primary outcome is the mean servings of sugar-sweetened and non-sugar-sweetened beverages consumed in the past 30 days, as measured by a validated questionnaire

intervention.description: A sugar-sweetened beverage warning label appropriate for the college-aged population was developed and applied to beverage stations at one large campus dining hall

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Currently enrolled student at the University
- Visited one of three large dining halls at least 100 times in the first 1.5 months of the academic year
Exclusion Criteria:
-
